Respectfully Translated by Imperial Decree Furthermore, good sons!
If bodhisattvas cultivate ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the perfection of meditation.
What are the ten?
First, extensively gathering merit and virtue;
Second, giving rise to much revulsion;
Third, arousing diligence;
Fourth, being endowed with much learning;
Fifth, diligently practicing without inverted instruction;
Sixth, practicing in accordance with the true Dharma;
Seventh, having sharp faculties;
Eighth, being endowed with a pure and good mind;
Ninth, well understanding calming and contemplation;
Tenth, not being attached to the characteristics of meditation.
What is extensively gathering merit and virtue?

It means that if a bodhisattva has long accumulated wholesome roots in the Mahayana Dharma, in those lives he will cultivate precepts well, be accepted by good spiritual friends, and be born in a place where he will always be born in a great Brahmin family, or a great Kshatriya family, or a great householder family, all with right faith.

In those lives, through those causes and conditions, he will further greatly increase his wholesome roots, and will always not be apart from good spiritual friends - who are those good spiritual friends?
It refers to Buddhas and Bodhisattvas - who can increase his wholesome roots from past lives, and due to the power of habitual practice, he will think like this:

'The great suffering in the world, the calamities in the world, the world without a moment's rest, long enduring entanglements covered by delusion, they are all caused by greed and desire as the cause, greed and desire as the condition.'
Understanding these causes and conditions is called the bodhisattva's extensive accumulation of blessings and virtues.
What is being disgusted with many things?
It means that if a bodhisattva, for this reason, gives rise to thought,
'I should not now, in the midst of the meeting of this world, become attached to and intimate with the objects of desire, for the objects of desire are false discrimination.
As the World-Honored One said:

Always with many kinds of causes and conditions one reviles desire, namely, desire is like a sharp spear, desire is like a sharp halberd, desire is like the edge of a sword, desire is like the edge of a knife, desire is like a poisonous snake, desire is like a lump of foam, desire is like a festering sore, desire is extremely foul-smelling.

' In this way, the mind gives rise to disgust towards the objects of desire, and then shaves off the beard and hair, dons the kaá¹£Äya robe, gives rise to correct faith, abandons the home life and goes forth.
This is the bodhisattva's frequent disgust.
What is the arousal of zeal?

It means that if a bodhisattva, due to going forth, gives rise to diligence, causes those who have not attained the Dharma to attain the Dharma, causes those who have not awakened to awaken, and causes those who have not realized to realize, this is the bodhisattva's giving rise to diligence.
What is being endowed with much learning?

It means that if a bodhisattva, due to these causes and conditions, is able to listen and accept all that is spoken, the Dharma of conventional truth and the Dharma of ultimate truth, this is the bodhisattva's being endowed with much learning.
What is the diligent practice of non-inverted instruction?

It means that if a bodhisattva, regarding the two kinds of Dharma, conventional and ultimate, is able to correctly instruct and diligently practice the non-inverted Dharma, this is the bodhisattva's diligent practice of non-inverted instruction.
What is practicing in accordance with the true Dharma?

It means that if a bodhisattva in the midst of right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration, the bodhisattva thus practices and realizes the right path, this is called the bodhisattva's practice in accordance with the Dharma.
What is it to have sharp faculties?
It means that because the bodhisattva practices the Dharma, his discerning wisdom becomes clear and his sharp faculties become even more excellent. This is called the bodhisattva's sharp faculties.
What is it to possess a completely wholesome mind?

It means that because the bodhisattva has sharp faculties, he often gives rise to disgust and avoids the great assembly and all kinds of worldly distractions, as well as thoughts of desire, anger, and harm, he completely avoids them and is also not attached to acquaintances, affection, fame, gain, and desirable things. With body and mind tranquil, he attains a completely wholesome mind. Because of the wholesome mind, he makes this observation:
'Now, in which dharmas does this mind of mine operate?'
Are they wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate?'
If one practices wholesome dharmas, one will attain a joyful and pure mind.
What are wholesome dharmas?
They are the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
If one practices unwholesome dharmas, one should arouse disgust and contemplate in many ways, diligently eliminating unwholesome dharmas.
What are unwholesome dharmas?
They are greed, hatred, and delusion.
Greed is of three kinds: upper, middle, and lower.
The upper kind of greed, to the utmost extent of body and mind, gives rise to attachment without a mind free from greed. Due to attachment, one does not give rise to shame in any situation.
What is shamelessness?
It means to be alone in one place, thinking like this, giving rise to seeking after various desired things, praising the objects of desire and manifesting one's own virtues. This is shamelessness.
What is lack of conscience?

Due to the causes and conditions of this craving, one goes against and disobeys one's parents and so forth, and gives rise to harm and injury towards them. One also has no shame or embarrassment towards other teachers and superiors, and displays one's own virtues. This is called lack of conscience.
Due to these causes and conditions, after death one falls into the evil destinies. This is called the highest level of craving.

The middling level of craving is when, when approaching various sensual objects, although one temporarily accomplishes something from beginning to end, one then gives rise to a mind of separation from craving and immediately gives rise to regret. This is called the middling level of craving.

The lowest level of craving is when, when approaching various sensual objects, whether one touches the body, speaks together, or gazes at each other, it is immediately extinguished. This is called the lowest level of craving.
To summarize, all the resources and necessities for sustaining life, for one who has desires, are all called the lowest level of craving.
There are three kinds of hatred, highest, middling, and lowest.
Those of the highest level of anger, upon arising of various objects of anger, give rise to extreme anger and are also violent, and completely commit the five heinous crimes.

Or they commit one of the heinous crimes, or slander the true Dharma. In general, such a collection of the five heinous crimes, in terms of calculation, fraction, analogy, up to the smallest unit of measurement, all cannot compare. Due to this cause and condition, when the body perishes and life ends, they fall into the great hells.

If they temporarily attain birth among humans, their body is black in appearance, their eyes are red and evil, and they are prone to anger and violence. Due to this cause and condition, they fall back into hell. This is called the highest level of anger.

Those of the middle level of anger, upon arising of various objects of anger, if they temporarily give rise to [anger] or commit unwholesome evil karma to a small extent, they immediately repent and quickly arouse countermeasures to make it cease. This is called the middle level of anger.

The lowest level of anger is when one gives rise to contempt and slander towards a loved one or harmonious object based on the conditions of anger, and although it may arise temporarily, one immediately feels regret in that moment, and quickly gives rise to countermeasures to make it cease. This is called the lowest level of anger.
There are three types of delusion: upper, middle, and lower.

The highest level of delusion is when in all situations, whether in action or stillness, there is nothing good done and no sorrow or grief, and one does not feel regret. This is called the highest level of delusion.

The middle level of delusion is when one gives rise to a small amount of unwholesome karma, and although it is accomplished, one quickly feels regret, confesses one's faults to fellow practitioners, and does not display one's own virtues. This is called the middle level of delusion.

The lowest level of delusion is when one does not violate the fundamental offenses in the precepts established by the TathÄgata, but violates the offenses of the first section of the precepts. This is called the lowest level of delusion.
Bodhisattvas who are free from these defiled dharmas will attain a well-pacified mind. Due to this goodness, they are able to be free from desire, love, craving, and attachment to desires.
Why is this?
It is because of the goodness of the mind.
If one practices indeterminate dharmas, it means one diligently contemplates with thoughts and ideas.
What are the indeterminate ones?

If the mind does not depend on the external or the internal, does not depend on the wholesome or the unwholesome, does not abide in the dharma of stillness or practice the dharma of contemplation, and the mind sinks down and becomes attached to sleep, it is like a person who has just woken up and whose eyes are unclear.
If the indeterminate mind appears, the mind is not clear and sharp, it is also like this.
Therefore, if bodhisattvas practice a wholesome mind, they will attain a joyful mind and a well-abiding mind. This is called bodhisattvas being endowed with a purely wholesome mind.
What is skillfully understanding stillness and contemplation?

It means that if a bodhisattva, due to possessing such a pure and good mind, is able to contemplate all dharmas, these dharmas are like illusions, these dharmas are like dreams, these dharmas are unwholesome, these dharmas are wholesome, these dharmas are liberation, these dharmas are not liberation.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

'All those dharmas have the mind as their basis and the mind as their forerunner. One should skillfully control the mind, skillfully subdue the mind, and skillfully understand the mind. By this, one will be able to skillfully control all dharmas.
' Also, skillfully subdue and skillfully understand, in this way one will be able to correctly contemplate all dharmas.

For this reason, one attains mental stillness. By fixing the mind on the mind, by stopping the mind on the mind, by abiding the mind on the mind, in this way diligently stilling the mind, one attains one-pointedness of mind.

Because the mind is one-pointed, it becomes samÄdhi and samÄhita. Due to this, one attains the joy and pleasure born of separation. Because the mind is joyful and at ease, one is able to completely separate from unwholesome dharmas and accomplish the dharmas of the first meditative absorption, which is endowed with investigation, analysis, and joy and pleasure born of separation.

Next, one is completely unhindered by investigation and analysis, and does not give rise to attachment to joy and pleasure. Having contemplated impermanence, one gradually arises from the first meditative absorption, and completely separates from the mind attached to investigation and analysis. One is then able to accomplish the dharmas of the second meditative absorption, which is endowed with concentration born of samÄdhi, joy and pleasure.

Next, one contemplates suffering in pleasure, and having contemplated suffering, one attains the practice of equanimity and mindfulness. As observed by the sages, one is able to correctly realize the sublime pleasure that manifests, and one is then able to accomplish the dharmas of the third meditative absorption, which is endowed with the sublime pleasure of separation from joy.
Next, in the third meditative absorption, one contemplates emptiness and draws forth the mind of the fourth meditative absorption.

In the four dhyÄnas, they eliminate the grasping of self, and because the grasping of self is eliminated, suffering and pleasure are all cut off. Because suffering and pleasure are cut off, the pleasant and unpleasant mental states that arose previously are also all abandoned, and they are able to accomplish the dhyÄna concentration method of pure equanimity and mindfulness.

Next, they make the image of their own body and the image of space equal, and make a single liberation. Observing in this way, they liberate all places and all kinds, transcend the conceptualization of form, and are free from obstruction. Because they transcend the conceptualization of form and are free from obstruction, they do not pay attention to those various conceptualizations, and take the characteristic of the limitless space as their object, and are able to accomplish the concentration method of the sphere of limitless space.ğŸ”½Next, in the sphere of limitless space, they simultaneously observe the sphere of limitless consciousness and take it as their characteristic, and are able to accomplish the concentration method of the sphere of limitless consciousness.

Next, transcending that sphere of limitless consciousness, they take the sphere of nothingness as their object and take it as their characteristic, and are able to accomplish the concentration method of the sphere of nothingness.

Next, transcending the sphere of nothingness, taking the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the object, one can accomplish the concentration of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Next, in the upper mind, without further objects, extinguishing all perceptions and feelings, leaving all mental activities, is called the concentration of cessation.
Such dharmas are what is meant by the bodhisattva's good understanding of calming and contemplation.
What is meant by not being attached to the characteristics of dhyÄna?

It means that although a bodhisattva enters the concentration of cessation, he does not delight in or become attached to quiescence, but is able to simultaneously give rise to a mind of loving-kindness, completely leaving behind the realms of enemies, friends, and neutrality, and bringing forth a vast mind. First, in one direction, he gives rise to the practice of immeasurable loving-kindness, universally observing and understanding liberation, and so it is in the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below.

After giving rise to the mind of loving-kindness, the mind of compassion, joy, and equanimity are also all as before, far removed from the realms of enemies, friends, opposition, compliance, and so forth, giving rise to the mind of vastness, pervading the ten directions, giving rise to the practices of compassion, joy, and equanimity without measure, universally observing and making them all liberation.

The bodhisattva is thus able to give rise to the five supernatural powers, yet does not take them as sufficient, does not become attached to the characteristics of meditation, and further seeks the supreme Dharma, perfecting the superior practices of bodhi. This is the bodhisattva's non-attachment to the characteristics of meditation.
Good man!
If the bodhisattva cultivates these ten kinds of dharmas, he will then attain the perfection of meditation.
Moreover, good man!
If the bodhisattva cultivates ten kinds of dharmas, he will then attain the perfection of superior wisdom.

What is skillfully understanding selflessness?

It means that bodhisattvas use right wisdom to contemplate form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness. When contemplating form, the arising of form cannot be apprehended, its accumulation also cannot be apprehended, and its cessation also cannot be apprehended;
The arising of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness cannot be apprehended, their accumulation cannot be apprehended, and their cessation cannot be apprehended.

The ultimate truth is not apart from the conventional truth. Whether it is the ultimate truth or the conventional truth, those two natures are merely verbal designations and do not have real substance.

Although bodhisattvas contemplate in this way, they do not abandon practices based on this principle. They diligently make energetic progress, benefiting sentient beings, as if their hair were on fire or their clothes were ablaze. This is the bodhisattvas' skill in non-self.
What is meant by being skilled in understanding karmic retribution?
It means that bodhisattvas contemplate in this way:
'The present world of aggregation is like an illusion, like a gandharva city, and its essence is empty.

If one becomes attached to the notion of self in regard to sentient beings and insentient beings, those sentient beings will thereby be unable to realize the right path. Those sentient beings will think like this:
If there is no self, no sentient beings, no life, no creeping things, no nurturers, no men, no pudgalas, no mind-born, no maá¹‡avakas, then there is no good or bad karma that can be indicated.
Who is the experiencer?
There is no real sentient being whose karmic retribution can be obtained.
Although the bodhisattva truly understands that there are no real sentient beings, he still manifests the retribution of good and evil karma.
The bodhisattva who truly understands with right wisdom, this is called the bodhisattva's good understanding of karmic retribution.
What is the good understanding of conditioned phenomena?
It means that if a bodhisattva, within conditioned phenomena, is able to skillfully awaken with right wisdom, he will have this thought:
'These conditioned phenomena have no moment of stillness, they flow and move with every thought, just like a dew drop and a mountain stream flowing swiftly without stopping.
How could there be a wise one who would give rise to attachment and delight in these phenomena?ğŸ”½If the pleasant objects disappear, he may then give rise to sorrow and distress.'

What is the good understanding of the revolving and flowing of cyclic existence?
It means that if a bodhisattva makes this kind of observation:
'Now, in this world, the characteristics of coming together, the darkness of ignorance, the continuity of reincarnation, are all bound by the rope of craving.

Because of craving, there is grasping. Due to the cause of grasping, wholesome and unwholesome actions are created. Because of the arising of wholesome and unwholesome actions, there is the continuity of existence. Because of existence, there is birth. Because of birth, there is old age and death. Due to the law of death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress arise and entangle one. Thus, there is the arising of the great mass of suffering.
The wheel of birth and death continues to revolve, like a water wheel turning up and down.'
The Bodhisattva, with his right wisdom, truly understands these dharmas. This is called the Bodhisattva's good understanding of the revolving and turning of reincarnation.
What is the good understanding of the Dharma of liberation from the cycle of reincarnation?
It is said that if a Bodhisattva makes this kind of observation:

'If there is no ignorance, then there will be no formations. If there are no formations, then there will be no consciousness. If there is no consciousness, then there will be no name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, and so on. If there is no birth, then there will be no old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress. All these dharmas will be completely extinguished.'
The bodhisattva, with his right wisdom, truly realizes these dharmas. This is the bodhisattva's skillful understanding of the Dharma of escaping from cyclic existence.

Why is it so?
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
I accept all sentient beings and make the lion's roar. I should rescue all sentient beings from the dangers of the wilderness of birth and death. I should not now alone escape from birth and death.

What is good understanding of the Great Vehicle?
It is said that if the bodhisattva is able to cultivate learning in all the learning gates, yet when learning, it cannot be attained, and the path of learning is also unattainable.

Although the bodhisattva does not attain those characteristics, he also does not fall into the view of annihilationism because of those causes and conditions. This is called the bodhisattva's good understanding of the Great Vehicle.

In all places, they always stay far away from worldly gains, offerings, and other things that are obstacles to the path of bodhi, and completely eliminate them. They then give rise to the methods of counteracting and destroying them. This is called a bodhisattva's ability to block the work of MÄra.
What is meant by being endowed with non-inverted wisdom?
It means that a bodhisattva, in all worldly literature, scriptures, and various activities, uses their superior wisdom to guide and study them.

The studies of bodhisattvas are only for the sake of maturing sentient beings, not for the sake of knowledge, fame, desire, and other things. Because of manifesting such supreme merits and virtues, diligently cultivating and learning, one will never fall into the wrong views of non-Buddhists. This is the bodhisattva's possession of non-inverted wisdom.

Good man!
If bodhisattvas cultivate these ten kinds of dharmas, they will attain the perfection of supreme wisdom.
